    • INTEG 375 / SOC 312

    Science & Technology in Society

    NOTE: This version of the syllabus is from Winter 2014. It will change before the class is offered in Winter 2015.

    Professor: John McLevey, PhD
    Department of Knowledge Integration
    Department of Sociology and Legal Studies
    University of Waterloo

    Office: EV1-212
    Office Hours: TBA
    Email: john.mclevey@uwaterloo.ca
    Phone: (519) 888-4567 ext. 31938

    Class Meetings: TBA

    Course Description

    This course is about (i.) the production of science and technology in specific contexts, and (ii.) struggles over scientific expertise and technology in the public sphere. Topics we will examine include the role of culture and organizations in knowledge creation, gender inequalities, expert advising and governance, science and social movements, the cultures of hacking, and the causes of “normal accidents” involving high-risk technology. The course has a strong collaborative learning component, and will include a lot of discussion.

    Learning Objectives

    • Understand and Apply Course Material
      • Explain how governments, organizations, communities, and social movements shape the creation of new technologies
      • Compare the regulation of secrecy, sharing, and collaboration in science and technology
      • Explain how network analysis has been used in research on science and technology
      • Describe gender inequalities in STEM fields, and historical changes in gender and computing
    • Develop Analytic Skills
      • Collect and clean publication data from the Web of Science
      • Use Web of Science data to create scholarly networks using Sci2 and Gephi1
      • Interpret network visualizations and statistics to describe scientific communities
      • Develop skills for collaborating on empirical research, and co-authoring research papers

    Assignments & Evaluation

    To do well in this course, you have to take the material seriously, consider it, and discuss it. You should be willing to change your mind on the basis of rational and respectful argument, but you do not have to agree with the readings, with what I say about them, or what others say about them. When you disagree, be respectful.

    Given the learning objectives outlined above, your grade in this course will be based on:

    TABLE 1: ASSIGNMENTS AND EVALUATION
    Task Value Due Dates
    3 memos posted to the course blog 30% Sign up
    Collaborative empirical research on scholarly networks 20% March 28
    Informal presentations of research 5% April 2 and 4
    Co-authored research paper (ideally groups of 2 or 4) 35% April 8
    Participation / engagement 10% Ongoing

    3 Memos Posted to the Course Blog (30%)

    We have a course blog (hosted on LEARN) that you will be expected to contribute to at least 3 times.2 You will sign up for specific readings to write about in our first class meeting. I will be grading these before every class, so they must be posted before the beginning of class.

    Your memos should be about 500 words. I will stop reading after 800 words. I expect them to be thoughtful, clear, and carefully edited. They should identify core points from the readings, offer any thoughts or reactions, and raise possible questions. You are encouraged but not required to relate them to any personal experiences.

    Each memo is due before the class begins, and will be graded as:

    • Check-minus: means the memo does not engage with the assigned reading, or engages the reading in a very superficial or erroneous way (roughly 7/10 or less)
    • Check: means the memo reflects on or poses thoughtful questions about the reading, and the writing is acceptable (roughly 8/10 or less)
    • Check-plus: means that the memo is very insightful, carefully thought through, and well written (roughly 9/10 or less)
    • Check-plus-plus: means that the memo far exceeds my expectations and is very well written (roughly 10/10)

    It is possible to get a check if the memo is good but the writing is rough, but you may receive a check-minus if the writing is very poor. Good writing alone will not guarantee that you will get a check-plus or a check-plus-plus. Please see the section below on academic integrity.

    Blog comments are part of your participation grade, so you should read the memos and post at least one comment every week. If you don’t like speaking up, this is one way to work on your participant / engagement grade. Disrespectful comments will not be tolerated. They will be as damaging to your participation grade as hostile behaviour in the classroom.

    Collaborative Empirical Research on Scholarly Networks (20%)

    Much of the research on science and technology requires understanding – and being able to think in terms of – networks. To help you learn how to do this, you will do your own empirical research on scholarly networks. You do not need to have a background in network analysis, quantitative sociology, statistics, mathematics, or programming in order to do the research for this class. If you tend to think in more qualitative or historical-comparative ways, you should know that there is a long and important tradition of qualitative social network analysis.

    60% of your final grade is set aside for your research on scholarly networks (including the analysis, writing, and presentation). You will work on the analysis throughout the semester during the Friday workshops (see the schedule below). In groups of 2-3, you will (1) choose a scholarly area or journal and collect publication data from the Web of Science database, (2) prepare the data and do basic analysis using Sci2, and (3) visualize and analyze the networks using Gephi.3 I will teach you how to do all of this in class. Together, we will develop group contracts and expectations documents that will set the context for your collaborations.

    You are free to choose the scholarly area / community that you want to explore in consultation with me. For example, you might look at the intellectual communities around journals that publish research in the sociology of science / science and technology studies (e.g. Social Studies of Science; Science, Technology, & Human Values; or Scientometrics), the history and / or philosophy of science (Synthese or Isis), or information science (e.g. The Canadian Journal of Information and Library Science, or Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology).4

    We will being using Sci2 and Gephi to analyze scholarly networks. All three are open source and can be downloaded free of cost. Please download them before class on February 7. I will remind you throughout the semester.

    We will set aside class time throughout the semester to work on your projects, discuss methodology, and address practical matters pertaining to content and text analysis.

    Presentation (5%)

    At the end of the semester, we will use some class time for you to present and discuss your research. These presentations are meant to be informal conversations about what you learned, but you should be prepared. All collaborators should say something about the research.

    Co-Authored Research Paper (35%)

    Your papers will present your research on scholarly networks, which means that your co-authors will be the same people you collaborated on the analysis with. Undergraduate students rarely co-author papers in university, but co-authoring is very common in most academic disciplines and in the public, private, and non-profit sectors. We will discuss co-authoring in detail throughout the semester, including how to avoid violating academic integrity policies. Together, we will develop group contracts and expectations documents that will set the context for your collaborations.

    Your paper should be roughly 10 single space pages (approx. 5,000 words) before references, have standard margins, and use a 12 pt font.5 Roughly 5-6 pages (approx. 2,000 – 3,000 words) of the paper should be set aside for a formal presentation of the results (including a visualization of the network), and a bigger picture discussion. Do not use a cover page. Put the title and your names in alphabetical order at the top of the first page. You are free to use any citation style you like, but you must use it consistently.

    You cannot submit the same work more than once. Although you may use some ideas that were raised in a memo on the blog, you can not directly copy text from your memo and use it in your research paper. If you are uncertain about whether or not you can use some text from a memo that you wrote, please consult me.

    You will submit your research papers to a dropbox on LEARN, which will be set up with the plagiarism detector Turn It In. If you don’t want to submit your research paper to Turn It In, you can schedule a 30-40 minute meeting to discuss your paper with me in detail.

    I will discuss my grading criteria in more detail in our class meetings, and I am happy to discuss your work in progress or when it is finished. If you feel you have been given a grade you don’t deserve, please wait 24 hours and then write a 500-600 word memo to me outlining the perceived error.

    Although I will be giving you feedback on your work throughout the term, I encourage you to make appointments with people at the writing centre. Their services are available to all UW students.

    Participation (10%)

    The quality of this course – like any other – depends on you being engaged. Your participation grade will be based on (a) contributions to class discussion, (b) small group discussion, (c) comments left on the course blog, and (d) attendance. If you really don’t like speaking up in class, you can participate more on the course blog.2

    Although I will not be assigning a participation grade until the end of the semester, I am happy to provide qualitative feedback on your participation throughout the semester.

    Attendance Policy

    This is a seminar, so your attendance makes a big difference. You are permitted to miss class twice throughout the semester without a medical note. For each additional class you miss without a medical note, I will take 1% off your participation grade. Consistent lateness will also negatively influence your participation grade.

    Submitting Work

    You will submit all work electronically. Please submit PDFs not Word documents, and do not give me any hard copies unless you have a very good reason.6

    Your research papers will be processed by the plagiarism detector Turn It In. If your group does not want to use Turn It In, you can choose to discuss your work with me in person during my office hours.

    Late Policy

    I will take off 5% a day for every day, or part of a day, that your research paper is late, including weekends.

    Required Readings

    You do not have to buy any books for this course. I have chosen excerpts of books that I can provide electronically under the fair dealing provision in the copyright act.7

    You should download three books that are available online for free under Creative Commons licenses:

    • Lawrence Lessig’s Code: Version 2.0
    • Gabriella Coleman’s Coding Freedom: The Ethics and Aesthetics of Hacking
    • Christopher Kelty’s Two Bits: The Cultural Significance of Free Software.

    Other required readings will be available on LEARN, or through the University of Waterloo library system.

    Although not required, I highly recommend getting copies of Janet Abbate’s Inventing the Internet, Heather Douglas’ Science, Policy, and the Value Free Ideal, and Rainee and Wellman’s Networked: The New Social Operating System.

    I am hoping that this course sparks your interest in social network analysis more broadly. If you want to pick up a book on the field, I have plenty of suggestions.

    Access Ability Services

    The AccessAbility Office, located in Needles Hall, Room 1132, collaborates with all academic departments to arrange appropriate accommodations for students with disabilities without compromising the academic integrity of the curriculum. If you require academic accommodations to lessen the impact of your disability, please register with the AccessAbility Office at the beginning of each academic term.

    Mental Health

    The University of Waterloo, the Faculty of Environment, and our Departments consider students’ well-being to be extremely important. We recognize that throughout the term students may face health challenges — physical and / or emotional. Please note that help is available. Mental health is a serious issue for everyone and can affect your ability to do your best work. Counselling Services8 is an inclusive, non-judgmental, and confidential space for anyone to seek support. They offer confidential counselling for a variety of areas including anxiety, stress management, depression, grief, substance use, sexuality, relationship issues, and much more.

    University Policies

    Academic Integrity

    In order to maintain a culture of academic integrity, members of the University of Waterloo community are expected to promote honesty, trust, fairness, respect and responsibility.9

    We will all uphold academic integrity policies at University of Waterloo, which include but are not limited to promoting academic freedom and a community free from discrimination and harassment. You can educate yourself on these policies — and the disciplinary processes in place to deal with violations — on the Office of Academic Integrity website.

    A student is expected to know what constitutes academic integrity, to avoid committing academic offense, and to take responsibility for his/her actions. A student who is unsure whether an action constitutes an offense, or who needs help in learning how to avoid offenses (e.g., plagiarism, cheating) or about “rules” for group work / collaboration should seek guidance from the course professor, academic advisor, or the Undergraduate Associate Dean. For information on categories of offences and types of penalties, students should refer to Policy 71, Student Discipline.10 For typical penalties, check Guidelines for Assessment of Penalties.11

    Grievances and Appeals

    A student who believes that a decision affecting some aspect of his / her university life has been unfair or unreasonable may have grounds for initiating a grievance. Read Policy 70 — Student Petitions and Grievances, Section 4.12 When in doubt please contact your Undergraduate Advisor for details.

    A decision made or penalty imposed under Policy 70 — Student Petitions and Grievances (other than a petition) or Policy 71 — (Student Discipline) may be appealed if there is a ground. A student who believes he/she has a ground for an appeal should refer to Policy 72 (Student Appeals).13

    Religious Observances

    Student needs to inform the instructor at the beginning of term if special accommodation needs to be made for religious observances that are not otherwise accounted for in the scheduling of classes and assignments.

    Feedback

    I will use LEARN’s Survey tool to solicit brief and informal course evaluations three or four times throughout the semester. These are anonymous, and will only take a few minutes of your time. The purpose is to make sure that we are moving at a comfortable pace, that you feel you understand the material, and that my teaching style is meeting your needs. I will use this ongoing feedback to make adjustments as the course progresses. Although you are not obligated to do so, please fill out the evaluations so that I can make this the best learning experience for you, and the best teaching experience for me.

    Class Format

    This course emphasizes collaborative learning. Group discussions will usually take place at the beginning of the class, followed by any lecture material at the end. When I lecture, it will mostly be to explain difficult concepts, or aspects of the readings that are not addressed in group discussion.

    Class Schedule and Assigned Readings

    We may adjust the reading schedule throughout the semester. All changes will be announced in class and via the course website on LEARN. I have included some recommended readings in case you are looking to learn more. They are not required reading.

    January 6, 8, 10: Introduction, Code and Law

    • Wednesday: Listen to “When Patents Attack” (An episode of the podcast This American Life.14
    • Friday: Listen to “When Patents Attack… Part 2” (you can skip the first 32 minutes, which recap the 2011 episode), Read Lessig’s “Code is Law” and “Four Puzzles from Cyberspace”

    January 13, 15, 17: Regulation and Legal Regimes

    • Monday: Lessig’s “Is-Ism: Is the way it is the way it must be?”
    • Wednesday: Coleman’s “The Life of a Free Software Hacker”
    • Friday: Coleman’s “A Tale of Two Legal Regimes”

    If you want to learn more: Coleman’s “The Craft and Craftiness of Hacking”, Lessig’s “Architectures of Control” and “Regulating Code”, Owen-Smith’s “The Institutionalization of Expertise in University licensing” (Note: assumes a background in organizational sociology.)

    January 20, 22, 24: Free / Open Source Hacking and Inventing the Internet

    • Monday: Kelty’s “The Movement”
    • Wednesday: Abbate’s “White Heat and Cold War: The Origins and Meaning of Packet Switching”
    • Friday: Abbate’s “Building the ARPANET: Challenges and Strategies”

    If you want to learn more: Kelty’s “The Movement” and “Writing Copyright Licences,” Evans’ “Industry Collaboration, Scientific Sharing, and the Dissemination of Knowledge,” and Owen-Smith and Powell’s “Knowledge Networks as Channels and Conduits: The Effects of Spillovers in the Boston Biotechnology Community” (Note: this is a challenging piece if you don’t have a background in social networks)

    January 27, 29, 31: Secrecy, Sharing, and Collaboration

    • Monday: Kelty’s “Coordinating Collaborations”
    • Wednesday: Merton’s “The Normative Structure of Science” in The Sociology of Science, and Delfanti’s “We are the Biohackers” from Biohackers: The Politics of Open Science. Spend some time reading online about Aaron Swartz.15
    • Friday: Network Analysis Workshop on basic concepts. Read pages 1-26 of Kaduschin’s Understanding Social Networks: Theories, Concepts, and Findings

    If you want to learn more: Stallman’s Free Software, Free Society: Selected Essays of Richard M. Stallman, selections from Open Sources: Voices from the Revolution, Levy’s Hackers: Heros of the Computer Revolution, Moody’s Rebel Code: Inside Linux and the Open Source Revolution, and Dreyfus’ Underground: Hacking, Madness, and Obsession on the Electronic Frontier. See also: Mitnick’s Ghost in the Wires, “Secrets of the Little Blue Box”, and “Hello, I Am Sabu…”.

    February 3, 5, 7: Gender, Science, and Technology

    • Monday: Abbate’s “Breaking Codes and Finding Trajectories: Women at the Dawn of the Digital Age.” You may also want to read some of the life history interviews Abbate conducted for her study, which are made available by the IEEE Global History Network.
    • Wednesday: Ecklund’s “Gender Segregation in Elite Academic Science”
    • Friday: Hargittai’s “Differences in Actual and Perceived Online Skills: The Role of Gender”

    If you want to learn more: Neff’s Venture Labor: Work and the Burden of Risk in Innovative Industries

    February 10, 12, 14: Scientific / Intellectual Networks

    • Monday: Network Analysis Workshop on network theory. Read Borgatti’s “Network Theory” and “Network analysis in the social sciences.”
    • Wednesday: Network Analysis Workshop on network analysis in the sociologies of science and knowledge. Read White’s “Scientific and Intellectual Networks.”
    • Friday: Network Analysis Workshop on network analysis in the sociologies of science and knowledge. Read Moody’s “A View From Above: The Evolving Sociological Landscape”

    If you want to learn more: All of Abbate’s Recoding Gender

    February 17, 19, 21: Reading week

    • No classes

    February 24, 26, 28: Metaknowledge and Scientific Consensus

    • Monday: Evans and Foster “Metaknowledge”
    • Wednesday: Shwed and Bearman “The Temporal Structure of Scientific Consensus Formation” (This is an extremely creative and fascinating network study. It’s also very technical. Do your best and we will talk about it in class.)
    • Friday: Network Analysis Workshop on collecting web of science data, and the basics of Sci2. Read Kieran Healy’s blog posts “A Co-Citation Network for Philosophy” and “Citation Networks in Philosophy, Some Follow Up”, and Scott Weingart’s blog posts “Networks Demystified 4: Co-Citation Analysis” and “Networks Demystified 7: Doing Co-Citation Analyses”.

    If you want to learn more: Vaughan’s “NASA Revisited,” Kleinman’s Impure Cultures: University Biology and the World of Commerce, and Klein and Kleinman’s “The Social Construction of Technology: Structural Considerations”

    March 3, 5, 7: Evaluation, Peer Review

    • Monday: Cole’s “Evaluation and the Characteristics of Scientists”
    • Wednesday: Lamont, Mallard, and Guetzkow’s “Beyond Blind Faith: Overcoming the Obstacles to Interdisciplinary Evaluation”
    • Friday: Guest Speaker on February 28: Dr. Kyle Siler is a Banting Postdoctoral Fellow (SSHRC) in Sociology at McMaster University. “How Peer Review Chooses and Changes Published Science”

    March 10, 12, 14: Science and Policy

    • Monday: Gauchat’s “Politicization of Science in the Public Sphere: A Study of Public Trust in the United States, 1974-2010”
    • Wednesday: Douglas’ “Introduction: Science Wars and Policy Wars”
    • Friday: Guest Speaker on March 14: Kosar Karimi Pour is a PhD Candidate in Sociology at McMaster University. “Mapping the Intellectual Structure of Middle Eastern Studies: An Author Co-citation Analysis”

    If you want to learn more: All of Heather Douglas Science, Policy, and the Value Free Ideal.

    March 17, 19, 20: Science and Policy

    • Monday: Jasanoff’s “Technologies of humility: Citizen participation in governing science”
    • Wednesday: Douglas’ “The Moral Responsibilities of Scientists”
    • Friday: Network Analysis Workshop We will spend time on any difficult concepts, and you can work on your projects in class.

    If you want to learn more: All of Homer-Dixon’s The Ingenuity Gap: Facing the Economic, Environmental, and Other Challenges of an Increasingly Complex and Unpredictable World

    March 24, 26, 28: Technology, Collaboration, and Community

    • Monday: Quan-Hasse, Cothrel, and Wellman’s “Instant Messaging for Collaboration: A Case Study of a High-Tech Firm”
    • Wednesday: Rainee and Wellman’s “The Mobile Revolution”
    • Friday: Social Network Analysis Workshop. We will spend time on any difficult concepts, and you can work on your projects in class.

    If you want to learn more: All of Rainee and Wellman’s Networked: The New Social Operating System, Turkel’s Simulation and Its Discontents

    March 31, April 2, 4: Choose one of the following

    Nanotechnology

    • Read “Introduction: The Social Scientific View of Nanotechnologies” in Harthorn and Mohr’s The Social Life of Nanotechnology, plus a chapter of your choosing.

    The Interface of the Life Sciences and the Social Sciences

    • Read Chapter 1 of Marion Blute’s Darwinian Sociocultural Evolution, Jeremy Freese on the “The Potential Relevances of Biology to Social Inquiry”, Listen to the Office Hours podcast Jeremy Freese on Sociology and Genetics, read Christakis and Fowler “The Spread of Obesity in a Large Social Network over 32 Years.”

    Risky Technology

    • Read selections from Perrow Normal Accidents: Living with High-Risk Technologies, or Vaughan The Challenger Launch Decision: Risky Technology, Culture, and Deviance at NASA

    Workplaces and Organizational Settings

    • Diane Vaughan’s “The Role of Organization in the Production of Techno-Scientific Knowledge,” Owen-Smith “Managing Laboratory Work Through Skepticism: Processes of Evaluation and Control”

    Ethnography of a Public Science: Meteorology

    • Read selections from Fine’s Authors of the Storm

    Globalization and Environmental Governance

    • Read Jasanoff’s “Testing Time for Climate Science,” and any two chapters from Jasanoff’s Earthy Politics: Local and Global in Environmental Governance.

    Artificial Intelligence and Cybernetics

    • Read Wolfe’s “Mind, Self, Society, and Computer: Artificial Intelligence and the Sociology of the Mind,” and a chapter from one of the following: Kurzweil’s The Singularity is Near: When Humans Transcend Biology, or The Age of Spiritual Machines: When Computers Exceed Human Intelligence, or Warwick’s I, Cyborg, or Artificial Intelligence: The Basics

    INFORMAL PRESENTATION OF RESEARCH ON APRIL 2 AND 4

    Notes

    4. In Winter 2014, the students in this class collaborated on network analyses of the growth of intellectual property law, changes in the intellectual structure of physics during WWII, the relationships between disciplines in the digital humanities and human computer interaction research, and the relationship between celebrity and academic status in astrophysics. ↩
